I don't like this idea. Using something like 'next' basically refers to the=
 order in which the Rules are called. But for most Rules I have seen, the i=
nteresting stuff happens in the Statements. So people say Rule, but really =
mean Statement. And for Statements 'next' doesn't make sense, while 'enclos=
ed' does.

Jens

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Malte Finsterwalder <malte@.=
..> wrote:
>
> I would prefer to give rules in the order they are applied.
=
> 
> How would I name the methods? Hmmm....
> 
> Maybe just:
> RuleChain.fi=
rst(new FirstRule()).next(new SecondRule()).next(new ThirdRule()); ?
> 
> G=
reetings,
>    Malte
> 
> On 30 July 2011 10:33, stefan.birkner <mail@...> =
wrote:
> > Hello,
> > sometimes you care about the order of rules. Therefor=
e I created a RuleChain, which is a rule itself:
> >
> > @Rule
> > public T=
estRule chain =3D RuleChain.outerRule(new FirstRule()).enclose(new SecondRu=
le());
> >
> > What do you thing about the naming outerRule and enclose?
> =
>
> > What do you think about starting with the outer rule instead of start=
ing with the inner rule:
> >
> > @Rule
> > public TestRule chain =3D RuleCh=
ain.innerRule(new SecondRule()).enclosedBy(new FirstRule());
> >

 want to see the code, look at https://github.com/stefanbirkner/junit/commi=
